name: Controversy and censorship
description: In this constellation, we look at the history of censorship in moving image history, from early blaxploitation films to videogames and beyond.

key_work.title: The Godmother of Blaxploitation
key_work.last_on_display_place: Australian Centre for the Moving Image
key_work.brief_description: Capturing the frustration and energy of the 1970s, Blaxploitation films created space for Black women to be action stars with top-line credit. Though it was originally coined as a derogatory term, Blaxploitation films like Coffy addressed racial injustice and the civil rights movements of the era.

start.title: Jackie Brown [DVD]
start.creator_credit: Quentin Tarantino, Lawrence Bender, Band Apart and Mighty Mighty Afrodite Productions
start.brief_description: Ruthless arms dealer Ordell Robbie (Samuel L. Jackson), who lives with perpetually stoned beach-babe Melanie (Bridget Fonda), teams with his old buddy Louis Gara (Robert De Niro), just released from prison after serving four years for armed robbery. ATF agent Ray Nicolette (Michael Keaton), and cop Mark Dargus (Michael Bowen), bust stewardess Jackie Brown (Pam Grier), who was smuggling money into the country for Ordell. Ordell springs Jackie, but when middle-aged bail bondsman Max Cherry (Robert Forster) picks her up at the jail, he’s attracted to her, and they choose a romantic route with detours. Mistrust and suspicions surface after Jackie pits Ordell and the cops against each other, convincing Ordell that she’s going to double-cross the cops. Adapted from Elmore Leonard’s novel “Rum Punch”, “Jackie Brown” is Tarantino’s homage to Blaxploitation cinema of the 1970s and a tribute to one of its feistiest characters - Pam Grier.

links.description: Jackie Brown (1997) is a homage to Pam Grier’s performance in Foxy Brown (1974), a highly influential but controversial blaxploitation film. On its UK release, all VHS were confiscated under the Obscene Publications Act due to its perceived potential to “deprave or corrupt” viewers.

end.title: The Chant of Jimmie Blacksmith
end.creator_credit: Fred Schepisi, Bruce Finlayson, The Film House, Victorian Film and Wendy Dickson

video_links.name: The Chant Of Jimmie Blacksmith Trailer

end.brief_description: In the late 1970s, non-Indigenous filmmakers wanting to support Indigenous Rights in Australia released films on Black Australia to mixed success. Fred Schepisi’s controversial The Chant of Jimmie Blacksmith (1978) divided audiences and demonstrated how non-Indigenous storytellers could co-opt Indigenous stories to great detriment.

constellations_other.name: Aboriginal History Archive
constellations_other.description: The Aboriginal History Archive at Victoria University, led by Gary Foley, is dedicated to the collection and preservation of First Peoples' stories and cultural material. The political activism of the Black Power movement in the 1970s is intersected with representation of Aboriginal actors on screen.

links.description: Like Foxy Brown (1974), Australian film The Chant of Jimmy Blacksmith (1978) was seized during the UK video nasty panic. Based on the true story of Jimmy Governor, a First Nations man whose experiences of exploitation and racism drove him to murder.

end.brief_description: It’s 1986 - Meredith Weiss takes a break from her career in the big city to deliver mail in her hometown. How will she experience two weeks in beautiful Providence Oaks, with its iconic lake and quirky community? And what will she do next? It’s up to you.

links.description: The Chant of Jimmy Blacksmith (1978) experience a brief UK ban but Australia has strict classification laws too – particularly around videogames. Lake (2021) is a peaceful game set about a mail carrier which was initially refused classification for a single scene involving marijuana.

end.title: Devotion
end.brief_description:
‘Devotion’ is a first-person atmospheric horror game set in the 1980s Taiwan.

The story centers around a seemingly ordinary family of three that lived in an old apartment complex. Explore the nostalgic house in the 80s where religion plays a significant role in their daily life. When one day the same house that once filled with joy and love had turned into a hell-like nightmare, and by venturing in the haunted and confined space, each puzzle leads you closer to the mysteries nested deep inside.

links.description: Videogames can also be censored by platforms, not governments. In 2020, Taiwanese studio Red Candle Games had their first-person horror game Devotion (2019) removed from digital videogame marketplace Steam following controversy over a critical reference to Chinese premier Xi Jinping,

end.title: [CENSORED]
end.creator_credit: Sari Braithwaite, Chloé Brugalé and Arenamedia
end.brief_description: An essay film by filmmaker and archivist Sari Braithwaite, [Censored] offers an overview of film censorship in Australia, told through an ever-changing collage of images compiled from the footage that was cut from films released domestically between 1958 and 1971.

constellations_other.name: My Hometown: Archives woven into new narrative
constellations_other.description: Offering viewers a snapshot of life on the road for an Australian touring band in the 1960s, 'My Hometown', directed by Sari Braithwaite was developed reimagining archival 8mm footage shot by drummer Leon Isackson.

constellations_other.name: Copy, transform and combine
constellations_other.description: You will see me (2020) repurposes material sourced from the history of the moving image – archival footage, news, interviews, documentaries, reality TV, video diaries and social media – to reflect on the way we perform in front of and reveal ourselves to the camera.

links.description: The history of censoring moving image works like Devotion (2019) has also inspired new work. Australian historian and filmmaker Sari Braithwaite made the documentary Censored (2018) to explore the archives of cut scenes from censored Australian films.
